speaker: BRABANTIO

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: Iago,--

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: What say'st thou, noble heart?

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: What will I do, thinkest thou?

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Why, go to bed, and sleep.

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: I will incontinently drown myself.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: If thou dost, I shall never love thee after. Why,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: thou silly gentleman!

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: It is silliness to live when to live is torment; and

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: then have we a prescription to die when death is our physician.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: O villainous! I have looked upon the world for four

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: times seven years; and since I could distinguish

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: betwixt a benefit and an injury, I never found man

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: that knew how to love himself. Ere I would say, I

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: would drown myself for the love of a guinea-hen, I

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: would change my humanity with a baboon.

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: What should I do? I confess it is my shame to be so

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: fond; but it is not in my virtue to amend it.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Virtue! a fig! 'tis in ourselves that we are thus

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: or thus. Our bodies are our gardens, to the which

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: our wills are gardeners: so that if we will plant

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: nettles, or sow lettuce, set hyssop and weed up

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: thyme, supply it with one gender of herbs, or

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: distract it with many, either to have it sterile

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: with idleness, or manured with industry, why, the

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: power and corrigible authority of this lies in our

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: wills. If the balance of our lives had not one

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: scale of reason to poise another of sensuality, the

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: blood and baseness of our natures would conduct us

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: to most preposterous conclusions: but we have

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: reason to cool our raging motions, our carnal

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: stings, our unbitted lusts, whereof I take this that

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: you call love to be a sect or scion.

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: It cannot be.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: It is merely a lust of the blood and a permission of

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: the will. Come, be a man. Drown thyself! drown

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: cats and blind puppies. I have professed me thy

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: friend and I confess me knit to thy deserving with

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: cables of perdurable toughness; I could never

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: better stead thee than now. Put money in thy

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: purse; follow thou the wars; defeat thy favour with

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: an usurped beard; I say, put money in thy purse. It

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: cannot be that Desdemona should long continue her

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: love to the Moor,-- put money in thy purse,--nor he

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: his to her: it was a violent commencement, and thou

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: shalt see an answerable sequestration:--put but

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: money in thy purse. These Moors are changeable in

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: their wills: fill thy purse with money:--the food

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: that to him now is as luscious as locusts, shall be

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: to him shortly as bitter as coloquintida. She must

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: change for youth: when she is sated with his body,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: she will find the error of her choice: she must

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: have change, she must: therefore put money in thy

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: purse. If thou wilt needs damn thyself, do it a

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: more delicate way than drowning. Make all the money

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: thou canst: if sanctimony and a frail vow betwixt

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: an erring barbarian and a supersubtle Venetian not

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: too hard for my wits and all the tribe of hell, thou

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: shalt enjoy her; therefore make money. A pox of

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: drowning thyself! it is clean out of the way: seek

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: thou rather to be hanged in compassing thy joy than

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: to be drowned and go without her.

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: Wilt thou be fast to my hopes, if I depend on

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: the issue?

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Thou art sure of me:--go, make money:--I have told

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: thee often, and I re-tell thee again and again, I

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: hate the Moor: my cause is hearted; thine hath no

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: less reason. Let us be conjunctive in our revenge

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: against him: if thou canst cuckold him, thou dost

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: thyself a pleasure, me a sport. There are many

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: events in the womb of time which will be delivered.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Traverse! go, provide thy money. We will have more

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: of this to-morrow. Adieu.

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: Where shall we meet i' the morning?

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: At my lodging.

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: I'll be with thee betimes.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Go to; farewell. Do you hear, Roderigo?

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: What say you?

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: No more of drowning, do you hear?

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: I am changed: I'll go sell all my land.

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Thus do I ever make my fool my purse:

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: For I mine own gain'd knowledge should profane,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: If I would time expend with such a snipe.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: But for my sport and profit. I hate the Moor:

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: And it is thought abroad, that 'twixt my sheets

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: He has done my office: I know not if't be true;

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: But I, for mere suspicion in that kind,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Will do as if for surety. He holds me well;

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: The better shall my purpose work on him.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Cassio's a proper man: let me see now:

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: To get his place and to plume up my will

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: In double knavery--How, how? Let's see:--

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: After some time, to abuse Othello's ear

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: That he is too familiar with his wife.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: He hath a person and a smooth dispose

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: To be suspected, framed to make women false.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: The Moor is of a free and open nature,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: That thinks men honest that but seem to be so,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: And will as tenderly be led by the nose

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: As asses are.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: I have't. It is engender'd. Hell and night

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Must bring this monstrous birth to the world's light.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: First Gentleman

text_entry: In quarter, and in terms like bride and groom

text_entry: Devesting them for bed; and then, but now--

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: As if some planet had unwitted men--

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Swords out, and tilting one at other's breast,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: In opposition bloody. I cannot speak

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Any beginning to this peevish odds;

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: And would in action glorious I had lost

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Those legs that brought me to a part of it!

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: How comes it, Michael, you are thus forgot?

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: I pray you, pardon me; I cannot speak.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Worthy Montano, you were wont be civil;

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: The gravity and stillness of your youth

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: The world hath noted, and your name is great

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: In mouths of wisest censure: what's the matter,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: That you unlace your reputation thus

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: And spend your rich opinion for the name

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Of a night-brawler? give me answer to it.

speaker: MONTANO
text_entry: Worthy Othello, I am hurt to danger:

speaker: MONTANO
text_entry: Your officer, Iago, can inform you,--

speaker: MONTANO
text_entry: While I spare speech, which something now

speaker: MONTANO
text_entry: offends me,--

speaker: MONTANO
text_entry: Of all that I do know: nor know I aught

speaker: MONTANO
text_entry: By me that's said or done amiss this night;

speaker: MONTANO
text_entry: Unless self-charity be sometimes a vice,

speaker: MONTANO
text_entry: And to defend ourselves it be a sin

speaker: MONTANO
text_entry: When violence assails us.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Now, by heaven,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: My blood begins my safer guides to rule;

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: And passion, having my best judgment collied,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Assays to lead the way: if I once stir,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Or do but lift this arm, the best of you

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Shall sink in my rebuke. Give me to know

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: How this foul rout began, who set it on;

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: And he that is approved in this offence,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Though he had twinn'd with me, both at a birth,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Shall lose me. What! in a town of war,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Yet wild, the people's hearts brimful of fear,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: To manage private and domestic quarrel,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: In night, and on the court and guard of safety!

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: 'Tis monstrous. Iago, who began't?

speaker: MONTANO
text_entry: If partially affined, or leagued in office,

speaker: MONTANO
text_entry: Thou dost deliver more or less than truth,

speaker: MONTANO
text_entry: Thou art no soldier.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Touch me not so near:

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: I had rather have this tongue cut from my mouth

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Than it should do offence to Michael Cassio;

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Yet, I persuade myself, to speak the truth

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Shall nothing wrong him. Thus it is, general.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Montano and myself being in speech,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: There comes a fellow crying out for help:

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: And Cassio following him with determined sword,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: To execute upon him. Sir, this gentleman

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Steps in to Cassio, and entreats his pause:

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Myself the crying fellow did pursue,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Lest by his clamour--as it so fell out--

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: The town might fall in fright: he, swift of foot,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Outran my purpose; and I return'd the rather

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: For that I heard the clink and fall of swords,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: And Cassio high in oath; which till to-night

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: I ne'er might say before. When I came back--

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: For this was brief--I found them close together,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: At blow and thrust; even as again they were

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: When you yourself did part them.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: More of this matter cannot I report:

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: But men are men; the best sometimes forget:

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Though Cassio did some little wrong to him,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: As men in rage strike those that wish them best,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Yet surely Cassio, I believe, received

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: From him that fled some strange indignity,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Which patience could not pass.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: I know, Iago,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Thy honesty and love doth mince this matter,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Making it light to Cassio. Cassio, I love thee

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: But never more be officer of mine.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Re-enter DESDEMONA, attended

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Look, if my gentle love be not raised up!

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: I'll make thee an example.

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: What's the matter?

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: All's well now, sweeting; come away to bed.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Sir, for your hurts, myself will be your surgeon:

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Lead him off.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: To MONTANO, who is led off

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Iago, look with care about the town,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: And silence those whom this vile brawl distracted.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Come, Desdemona: 'tis the soldiers' life

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: To have their balmy slumbers waked with strife.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Exeunt all but IAGO and CASSIO

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: What, are you hurt, lieutenant?

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Ay, past all surgery.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Marry, heaven forbid!

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Reputation, reputation, reputation! O, I have lost

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: my reputation! I have lost the immortal part of

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: myself, and what remains is bestial. My reputation,

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Iago, my reputation!

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: As I am an honest man, I thought you had received

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: some bodily wound; there is more sense in that than

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: in reputation. Reputation is an idle and most false

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: imposition: oft got without merit, and lost without

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: deserving: you have lost no reputation at all,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: unless you repute yourself such a loser. What, man!

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: there are ways to recover the general again: you

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: are but now cast in his mood, a punishment more in

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: policy than in malice, even so as one would beat his

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: offenceless dog to affright an imperious lion: sue

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: to him again, and he's yours.

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: I will rather sue to be despised than to deceive so

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: good a commander with so slight, so drunken, and so

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: indiscreet an officer. Drunk? and speak parrot?

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: and squabble? swagger? swear? and discourse

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: fustian with one's own shadow? O thou invisible

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: spirit of wine, if thou hast no name to be known by,

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: let us call thee devil!

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: What was he that you followed with your sword? What

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: had he done to you?

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: I know not.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Is't possible?

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: I remember a mass of things, but nothing distinctly;

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: a quarrel, but nothing wherefore. O God, that men

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: should put an enemy in their mouths to steal away

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: their brains! that we should, with joy, pleasance

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: revel and applause, transform ourselves into beasts!

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Why, but you are now well enough: how came you thus

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: recovered?

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: It hath pleased the devil drunkenness to give place

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: to the devil wrath; one unperfectness shows me

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: another, to make me frankly despise myself.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Come, you are too severe a moraler: as the time,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: the place, and the condition of this country

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: stands, I could heartily wish this had not befallen;

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: but, since it is as it is, mend it for your own good.

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: I will ask him for my place again; he shall tell me

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: I am a drunkard! Had I as many mouths as Hydra,

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: such an answer would stop them all. To be now a

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: sensible man, by and by a fool, and presently a

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: beast! O strange! Every inordinate cup is

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: unblessed and the ingredient is a devil.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Come, come, good wine is a good familiar creature,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: if it be well used: exclaim no more against it.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: And, good lieutenant, I think you think I love you.

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: I have well approved it, sir. I drunk!

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: You or any man living may be drunk! at a time, man.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: I'll tell you what you shall do. Our general's wife

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: is now the general: may say so in this respect, for

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: that he hath devoted and given up himself to the

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: contemplation, mark, and denotement of her parts and

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: graces: confess yourself freely to her; importune

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: her help to put you in your place again: she is of

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: so free, so kind, so apt, so blessed a disposition,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: she holds it a vice in her goodness not to do more

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: than she is requested: this broken joint between

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: you and her husband entreat her to splinter; and, my

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: fortunes against any lay worth naming, this

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: crack of your love shall grow stronger than it was before.

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: You advise me well.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: I protest, in the sincerity of love and honest kindness.

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: I think it freely; and betimes in the morning I will

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: beseech the virtuous Desdemona to undertake for me:

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: I am desperate of my fortunes if they cheque me here.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: You are in the right. Good night, lieutenant; I

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: must to the watch.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: CASSIO: Good night, honest Iago.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: And what's he then that says I play the villain?

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: When this advice is free I give and honest,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Probal to thinking and indeed the course

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: To win the Moor again? For 'tis most easy

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: The inclining Desdemona to subdue

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: In any honest suit: she's framed as fruitful

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: As the free elements. And then for her

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: To win the Moor--were't to renounce his baptism,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: All seals and symbols of redeemed sin,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: His soul is so enfetter'd to her love,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: That she may make, unmake, do what she list,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Even as her appetite shall play the god

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: With his weak function. How am I then a villain

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: To counsel Cassio to this parallel course,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Directly to his good? Divinity of hell!

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: When devils will the blackest sins put on,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: They do suggest at first with heavenly shows,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: As I do now: for whiles this honest fool

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Plies Desdemona to repair his fortunes

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: And she for him pleads strongly to the Moor,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: I'll pour this pestilence into his ear,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: That she repeals him for her body's lust;

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: And by how much she strives to do him good,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: She shall undo her credit with the Moor.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: So will I turn her virtue into pitch,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: And out of her own goodness make the net

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: That shall enmesh them all.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Re-enter RODERIGO

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: How now, Roderigo!

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: I do follow here in the chase, not like a hound that

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: hunts, but one that fills up the cry. My money is

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: almost spent; I have been to-night exceedingly well

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: cudgelled; and I think the issue will be, I shall

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: have so much experience for my pains, and so, with

speaker: RODERIGO
text_entry: no money at all and a little more wit, return again to Venice.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: How poor are they that have not patience!

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: What wound did ever heal but by degrees?

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Thou know'st we work by wit, and not by witchcraft;

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: And wit depends on dilatory time.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Does't not go well? Cassio hath beaten thee.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: And thou, by that small hurt, hast cashier'd Cassio:

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Though other things grow fair against the sun,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Yet fruits that blossom first will first be ripe:

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Content thyself awhile. By the mass, 'tis morning;

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Pleasure and action make the hours seem short.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Retire thee; go where thou art billeted:

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Away, I say; thou shalt know more hereafter:

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Nay, get thee gone.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Exit RODERIGO

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Two things are to be done:

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: My wife must move for Cassio to her mistress;

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: I'll set her on;

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Myself the while to draw the Moor apart,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: And bring him jump when he may Cassio find

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Soliciting his wife: ay, that's the way

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Dull not device by coldness and delay.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: SCENE I. Before the castle.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Enter CASSIO and some Musicians

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Masters, play here; I will content your pains;

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Something that's brief; and bid 'Good morrow, general.'

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Music

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Enter Clown

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Why masters, have your instruments been in Naples,

speaker: Clown
text_entry: that they speak i' the nose thus?

speaker: First Musician
text_entry: How, sir, how!

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Are these, I pray you, wind-instruments?

speaker: First Musician
text_entry: Ay, marry, are they, sir.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: O, thereby hangs a tail.

speaker: First Musician
text_entry: Whereby hangs a tale, sir?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Marry. sir, by many a wind-instrument that I know.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: But, masters, here's money for you: and the general

speaker: Clown
text_entry: so likes your music, that he desires you, for love's

speaker: Clown
text_entry: sake, to make no more noise with it.

speaker: First Musician
text_entry: Well, sir, we will not.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: If you have any music that may not be heard, to't

speaker: Clown
text_entry: again: but, as they say to hear music the general

speaker: Clown
text_entry: does not greatly care.

speaker: First Musician
text_entry: We have none such, sir.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Then put up your pipes in your bag, for I'll away:

speaker: Clown
text_entry: go; vanish into air; away!

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Exeunt Musicians

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Dost thou hear, my honest friend?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: No, I hear not your honest friend; I hear you.

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Prithee, keep up thy quillets. There's a poor piece

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: of gold for thee: if the gentlewoman that attends

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: the general's wife be stirring, tell her there's

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: one Cassio entreats her a little favour of speech:

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: wilt thou do this?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: She is stirring, sir: if she will stir hither, I

speaker: Clown
text_entry: shall seem to notify unto her.

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Do, good my friend.

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Exit Clown

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Enter IAGO

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: In happy time, Iago.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: You have not been a-bed, then?

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Why, no; the day had broke

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Before we parted. I have made bold, Iago,

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: To send in to your wife: my suit to her

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Is, that she will to virtuous Desdemona

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Procure me some access.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: I'll send her to you presently;

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: And I'll devise a mean to draw the Moor

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Out of the way, that your converse and business

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: May be more free.

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: I humbly thank you for't.

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Exit IAGO

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: I never knew

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: A Florentine more kind and honest.

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Enter EMILIA

speaker: EMILIA
text_entry: Good morrow, good Lieutenant: I am sorry

speaker: EMILIA
text_entry: For your displeasure; but all will sure be well.

speaker: EMILIA
text_entry: The general and his wife are talking of it;

speaker: EMILIA
text_entry: And she speaks for you stoutly: the Moor replies,

speaker: EMILIA
text_entry: That he you hurt is of great fame in Cyprus,

speaker: EMILIA
text_entry: And great affinity, and that in wholesome wisdom

speaker: EMILIA
text_entry: He might not but refuse you; but he protests he loves you

speaker: EMILIA
text_entry: And needs no other suitor but his likings

speaker: EMILIA
text_entry: To take the safest occasion by the front

speaker: EMILIA
text_entry: To bring you in again.

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Yet, I beseech you,

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: If you think fit, or that it may be done,

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Give me advantage of some brief discourse

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: With Desdemona alone.

speaker: EMILIA
text_entry: Pray you, come in;

speaker: EMILIA
text_entry: I will bestow you where you shall have time

speaker: EMILIA
text_entry: To speak your bosom freely.

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: I am much bound to you.

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: SCENE II. A room in the castle.

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Enter OTHELLO, IAGO, and Gentlemen

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: These letters give, Iago, to the pilot;

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: And by him do my duties to the senate:

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: That done, I will be walking on the works;

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Repair there to me.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Well, my good lord, I'll do't.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: This fortification, gentlemen, shall we see't?

speaker: Gentleman
text_entry: We'll wait upon your lordship.

speaker: Gentleman
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Gentleman
text_entry: SCENE III. The garden of the castle.

speaker: Gentleman
text_entry: Enter DESDEMONA, CASSIO, and EMILIA

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: Be thou assured, good Cassio, I will do

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: All my abilities in thy behalf.

speaker: EMILIA
text_entry: Good madam, do: I warrant it grieves my husband,

speaker: EMILIA
text_entry: As if the case were his.

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: O, that's an honest fellow. Do not doubt, Cassio,

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: But I will have my lord and you again

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: As friendly as you were.

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Bounteous madam,

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Whatever shall become of Michael Cassio,

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: He's never any thing but your true servant.

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: I know't; I thank you. You do love my lord:

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: You have known him long; and be you well assured

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: He shall in strangeness stand no further off

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: Than in a polite distance.

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Ay, but, lady,

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: That policy may either last so long,

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Or feed upon such nice and waterish diet,

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Or breed itself so out of circumstance,

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: That, I being absent and my place supplied,

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: My general will forget my love and service.

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: Do not doubt that; before Emilia here

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: I give thee warrant of thy place: assure thee,

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: If I do vow a friendship, I'll perform it

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: To the last article: my lord shall never rest;

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: I'll watch him tame and talk him out of patience;

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: His bed shall seem a school, his board a shrift;

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: I'll intermingle every thing he does

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: With Cassio's suit: therefore be merry, Cassio;

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: For thy solicitor shall rather die

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: Than give thy cause away.

speaker: EMILIA
text_entry: Madam, here comes my lord.

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Madam, I'll take my leave.

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: Why, stay, and hear me speak.

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Madam, not now: I am very ill at ease,

speaker: CASSIO
text_entry: Unfit for mine own purposes.

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: Well, do your discretion.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: The Moor already changes with my poison:

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Dangerous conceits are, in their natures, poisons.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Which at the first are scarce found to distaste,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: But with a little act upon the blood.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Burn like the mines of Sulphur. I did say so:

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Look, where he comes!

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Re-enter OTHELLO

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Not poppy, nor mandragora,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Nor all the drowsy syrups of the world,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Shall ever medicine thee to that sweet sleep

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Which thou owedst yesterday.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Ha! ha! false to me?

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Why, how now, general! no more of that.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Avaunt! be gone! thou hast set me on the rack:

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: I swear 'tis better to be much abused

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Than but to know't a little.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: How now, my lord!

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: What sense had I of her stol'n hours of lust?

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: I saw't not, thought it not, it harm'd not me:

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: I slept the next night well, was free and merry;

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: I found not Cassio's kisses on her lips:

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: He that is robb'd, not wanting what is stol'n,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Let him not know't, and he's not robb'd at all.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: I am sorry to hear this.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: I had been happy, if the general camp,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Pioners and all, had tasted her sweet body,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: So I had nothing known. O, now, for ever

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Farewell the tranquil mind! farewell content!

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Farewell the plumed troop, and the big wars,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: That make ambition virtue! O, farewell!

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Farewell the neighing steed, and the shrill trump,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: The spirit-stirring drum, the ear-piercing fife,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: The royal banner, and all quality,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Pride, pomp and circumstance of glorious war!

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: And, O you mortal engines, whose rude throats

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: The immortal Jove's dead clamours counterfeit,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Farewell! Othello's occupation's gone!

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Is't possible, my lord?

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Villain, be sure thou prove my love a whore,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Be sure of it; give me the ocular proof:

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Or by the worth of man's eternal soul,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Thou hadst been better have been born a dog

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Than answer my waked wrath!

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Is't come to this?

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Make me to see't; or, at the least, so prove it,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: That the probation bear no hinge nor loop

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: To hang a doubt on; or woe upon thy life!

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: My noble lord,--

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: If thou dost slander her and torture me,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Never pray more; abandon all remorse;

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: On horror's head horrors accumulate;

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Do deeds to make heaven weep, all earth amazed;

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: For nothing canst thou to damnation add

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Greater than that.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: O grace! O heaven forgive me!

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Are you a man? have you a soul or sense?

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: God be wi' you; take mine office. O wretched fool.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: That livest to make thine honesty a vice!

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: O monstrous world! Take note, take note, O world,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: To be direct and honest is not safe.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: I thank you for this profit; and from hence

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: I'll love no friend, sith love breeds such offence.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Nay, stay: thou shouldst be honest.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: I should be wise, for honesty's a fool

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: And loses that it works for.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: By the world,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: I think my wife be honest and think she is not;

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: I think that thou art just and think thou art not.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: I'll have some proof. Her name, that was as fresh

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: As Dian's visage, is now begrimed and black

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: As mine own face. If there be cords, or knives,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Poison, or fire, or suffocating streams,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: I'll not endure it. Would I were satisfied!

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: I see, sir, you are eaten up with passion:

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: I do repent me that I put it to you.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: You would be satisfied?

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Would! nay, I will.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: And may: but, how? how satisfied, my lord?

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Would you, the supervisor, grossly gape on--

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Behold her topp'd?

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Death and damnation! O!

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: It were a tedious difficulty, I think,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: To bring them to that prospect: damn them then,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: If ever mortal eyes do see them bolster

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: More than their own! What then? how then?

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: What shall I say? Where's satisfaction?

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: It is impossible you should see this,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Were they as prime as goats, as hot as monkeys,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: As salt as wolves in pride, and fools as gross

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: As ignorance made drunk. But yet, I say,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: If imputation and strong circumstances,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Which lead directly to the door of truth,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Will give you satisfaction, you may have't.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Give me a living reason she's disloyal.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: I do not like the office:

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: But, sith I am enter'd in this cause so far,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Prick'd to't by foolish honesty and love,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: I will go on. I lay with Cassio lately;

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: And, being troubled with a raging tooth,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: I could not sleep.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: There are a kind of men so loose of soul,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: That in their sleeps will mutter their affairs:

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: One of this kind is Cassio:

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: In sleep I heard him say 'Sweet Desdemona,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Let us be wary, let us hide our loves;'

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: And then, sir, would he gripe and wring my hand,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Cry 'O sweet creature!' and then kiss me hard,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: As if he pluck'd up kisses by the roots

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: That grew upon my lips: then laid his leg

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Over my thigh, and sigh'd, and kiss'd; and then

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Cried 'Cursed fate that gave thee to the Moor!'

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: O monstrous! monstrous!

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Nay, this was but his dream.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: But this denoted a foregone conclusion:

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: 'Tis a shrewd doubt, though it be but a dream.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: And this may help to thicken other proofs

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: That do demonstrate thinly.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: I'll tear her all to pieces.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Nay, but be wise: yet we see nothing done;

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: She may be honest yet. Tell me but this,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Have you not sometimes seen a handkerchief

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Spotted with strawberries in your wife's hand?

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: I gave her such a one; 'twas my first gift.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: I know not that; but such a handkerchief--

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: I am sure it was your wife's--did I to-day

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: See Cassio wipe his beard with.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: If it be that--

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: If it be that, or any that was hers,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: It speaks against her with the other proofs.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: O, that the slave had forty thousand lives!

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: One is too poor, too weak for my revenge.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Now do I see 'tis true. Look here, Iago;

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: All my fond love thus do I blow to heaven.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: 'Tis gone.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Arise, black vengeance, from thy hollow cell!

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Yield up, O love, thy crown and hearted throne

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: To tyrannous hate! Swell, bosom, with thy fraught,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: For 'tis of aspics' tongues!

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Yet be content.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: O, blood, blood, blood!

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Patience, I say; your mind perhaps may change.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Never, Iago: Like to the Pontic sea,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Whose icy current and compulsive course

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Ne'er feels retiring ebb, but keeps due on

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: To the Propontic and the Hellespont,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Even so my bloody thoughts, with violent pace,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Shall ne'er look back, ne'er ebb to humble love,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Till that a capable and wide revenge

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Swallow them up. Now, by yond marble heaven,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Kneels

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: In the due reverence of a sacred vow

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: I here engage my words.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Do not rise yet.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Kneels

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Witness, you ever-burning lights above,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: You elements that clip us round about,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Witness that here Iago doth give up

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: The execution of his wit, hands, heart,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: To wrong'd Othello's service! Let him command,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: And to obey shall be in me remorse,

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: What bloody business ever.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: They rise

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: I greet thy love,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Not with vain thanks, but with acceptance bounteous,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: And will upon the instant put thee to't:

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Within these three days let me hear thee say

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: That Cassio's not alive.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: My friend is dead; 'tis done at your request:

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: But let her live.

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Damn her, lewd minx! O, damn her!

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: Come, go with me apart; I will withdraw,

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: To furnish me with some swift means of death

speaker: OTHELLO
text_entry: For the fair devil. Now art thou my lieutenant.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: I am your own for ever.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: SCENE IV. Before the castle.

speaker: IAGO
text_entry: Enter DESDEMONA, EMILIA, and Clown

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: Do you know, sirrah, where Lieutenant Cassio lies?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: I dare not say he lies any where.

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: Why, man?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: He's a soldier, and for one to say a soldier lies,

speaker: Clown
text_entry: is stabbing.

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: Go to: where lodges he?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: To tell you where he lodges, is to tell you where I lie.

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: Can any thing be made of this?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: I know not where he lodges, and for me to devise a

speaker: Clown
text_entry: lodging and say he lies here or he lies there, were

speaker: Clown
text_entry: to lie in mine own throat.

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: Can you inquire him out, and be edified by report?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: I will catechise the world for him; that is, make

speaker: Clown
text_entry: questions, and by them answer.

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: Seek him, bid him come hither: tell him I have

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: moved my lord on his behalf, and hope all will be well.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: To do this is within the compass of man's wit: and

speaker: Clown
text_entry: therefore I will attempt the doing it.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: Where should I lose that handkerchief, Emilia?

text_entry: I know not, madam.

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: Believe me, I had rather have lost my purse

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: Full of crusadoes: and, but my noble Moor

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: Is true of mind and made of no such baseness

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: As jealous creatures are, it were enough

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: To put him to ill thinking.

speaker: EMILIA
text_entry: Is he not jealous?

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: Who, he? I think the sun where he was born

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: Drew all such humours from him.

speaker: EMILIA
text_entry: Look, where he comes.

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: I will not leave him now till Cassio

speaker: DESDEMONA
text_entry: Be call'd to him.

speaker: DESDEMONA
